home.title: Welcome to Fung.es
home.subtitle: Your AI-powered foraging companion
home.description: Discover, identify, and learn about wild edibles with the help of artificial intelligence

map.title: Foraging Map
map.subtitle: Find the best spots for wild edibles

chanterelle.name: Chanterelle
chanterelle.description: A golden-yellow mushroom with a distinctive funnel shape and fruity apricot-like aroma. Highly prized for its excellent flavor and meaty texture.
chanterelle.howTo: Look for chanterelles in mixed forests, particularly under oak and pine trees. They grow in clusters and prefer moist, well-drained soil. Harvest by gently twisting and pulling from the base.

porcini.name: Porcini
porcini.description: A large, meaty mushroom with a thick stem and brown cap. Known for its rich, nutty flavor and firm texture. One of the most sought-after wild mushrooms.
porcini.howTo: Find porcini in deciduous and coniferous forests, often near oak, beech, and pine trees. They prefer well-drained soil and can grow quite large. Cut at the base to harvest.

morel.name: Morel
morel.description: A distinctive mushroom with a honeycomb-like cap and hollow stem. Highly prized for its unique flavor and texture. Often found in spring after forest fires.
morel.howTo: Search for morels in disturbed areas, burned forests, and near dead or dying trees. They appear in spring and early summer. Cut at the base and always cook thoroughly.

blackberry.name: Blackberry
blackberry.description: A sweet, juicy berry that grows on thorny bushes. Rich in antioxidants and vitamins. Available in late summer and early fall.
blackberry.howTo: Look for blackberry bushes in open areas, along trails, and in forest edges. Pick only fully ripe, dark berries. Wear gloves to avoid thorns.

elderberry.name: Elderberry
elderberry.description: Small, dark purple berries that grow in clusters on elder trees. Used for jams, syrups, and traditional medicine. Must be cooked before consumption.
elderberry.howTo: Find elder trees in moist areas, along streams, and in forest edges. Harvest entire clusters when berries are fully ripe. Remove stems and cook thoroughly.

nettle.name: Stinging Nettle
nettle.description: A nutritious green plant with stinging hairs. Rich in iron, vitamins, and minerals. Used in soups, teas, and as a spinach substitute.
nettle.howTo: Wear gloves when harvesting nettles. Pick young, tender leaves in spring. Avoid flowering plants. Blanch or cook to remove stinging properties.

dandelion.name: Dandelion
dandelion.description: A common weed with bright yellow flowers and nutritious leaves. All parts are edible and rich in vitamins and minerals.
dandelion.howTo: Harvest young leaves in spring for salads, or use mature leaves for cooking. Dig roots in fall for tea. Pick flowers for wine or fritters.

hazelnut.name: Hazelnut
hazelnut.description: Sweet, nutty kernels encased in hard shells. Rich in protein, healthy fats, and vitamins. Available in late summer and fall.
hazelnut.howTo: Look for hazelnut trees in forest edges and open areas. Harvest when nuts fall to the ground. Remove husks and dry thoroughly before storing.

wildGarlic.name: Wild Garlic
wildGarlic.description: A pungent herb with broad leaves and white flowers. Strong garlic flavor and aroma. Used as a seasoning and in pesto.
wildGarlic.howTo: Find wild garlic in moist, shady areas and forest floors. Harvest leaves before flowering for best flavor. Use fresh or preserve in oil.

chickenOfTheWoods.name: Chicken of the Woods
chickenOfTheWoods.description: A bright orange or yellow shelf mushroom that grows on trees. Named for its chicken-like texture when cooked. Excellent meat substitute.
chickenOfTheWoods.howTo: Look for this mushroom on dead or dying trees, particularly oak. Harvest young, tender specimens. Cut from the tree and clean thoroughly.
